reviews.text:
Credit Scoring Logic & Explainability Expectations
At the heart of the platform is the credit scoring and decisioning engine – the logic that evaluates an SME’s creditworthiness.
reviews.reason_text: Discusses expectations without enforceable behavior.

reviews.text: This engine will utilize a combination of analytical models and business rules to produce a risk assessment for each application.
reviews.reason_text: This engine will utilize a combination of analytical models and business rules to produce a risk assessment for each application.

reviews.text: Equally important to what the decision is, however, is why: stakeholders and regulators expect the system to provide clear, human-understandable explanations for its credit decisions.
reviews.reason_text: Stakeholders and regulators expect the system to provide clear, human-understandable explanations for its credit decisions.

reviews.text: Below, we outline the approach to the scoring logic and how we will ensure transparency and explainability:
reviews.reason_text: Below, we outline the approach to the scoring logic and how we will ensure transparency and explainability.

reviews.text: Multi-Factor Risk Assessment: The credit scoring logic considers a wide range of factors about the SME.
reviews.reason_text: Describes factors but not enforceable behavior.

reviews.text: These include financial ratios derived from documents (e.g. debt-to-income ratio, profit margins, current ratio), cash flow patterns from bank data (e.g. frequency of negative balances, volatility of revenues), payment history (e.g. any missed loan/credit payments), and behavioral indicators (such as consistency in paying invoices on time).
reviews.reason_text: Details on factors without enforcing action.

reviews.text: The platform’s model will likely be a machine learning-based risk model or an enhanced scorecard that weighs these factors to predict the probability of default or overall credit risk grade.
reviews.reason_text: Predicting model type isn't enforceable.

reviews.text: Regardless of the modeling technique, it will be developed to align with domain expertise – for example, higher stable cash flow and strong financials should yield a better score, whereas erratic income or heavy existing debt will lower it, mirroring common credit principles.
reviews.reason_text: It will be developed to align with domain expertise.

reviews.text: We will calibrate the model using historical data (loan outcomes, defaults) to ensure it has strong predictive power.
reviews.reason_text: We will calibrate the model using historical data (loan outcomes, defaults) to ensure it has strong predictive power.

reviews.text: The output will typically be a numerical credit score or rating for the SME, and possibly expected loss metrics, which translate into an automated recommendation (e.g., “approve”, “approve with conditions”, or “refer to manual review/decline”).
reviews.reason_text: The output will typically be a numerical credit score or rating for the SME, and possibly expected loss metrics.

reviews.text: However, unlike a mysterious “black box”, this model’s workings will be made as transparent as possible to the end users.
reviews.reason_text: This model’s workings will be made as transparent as possible to the end users.

reviews.reason_text: Implies rule enforcement.

reviews.reason_text: For instance, “Decline if bankruptcy filed in last 5 years,” or “If annual revenue < $50k, flag for manual review regardless of score.”

Versioning & Continuous Learning Expectations
Credit risk models and decision policies cannot remain static; they must evolve with changing economic conditions, new data, and lessons learned from outcomes.

Model Versioning and Tracking: Each iteration of the credit scoring model (and major rule set changes) will be version-controlled within the platform.
